summary: This is an email chain from March 2020 regarding a French financial intelligence unit (TRACFIN) request to FinCEN. The request concerns a 50,000 Euro transaction from Jeffrey Epstein's US Virgin Islands company, Gratitude America LTD, to a French cultural association. The emails document internal U.S. government deconfliction to approve sharing information with France, noting Epstein's status as a Politically Exposed Person (PEP).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Beneficial owner of Gratitude America LTD
persons.context: Identified as the deceased beneficial owner of the company involved in the suspicious transaction, accused of sex trafficking and misappropriating funds, and flagged as a Politically Exposed Person (PEP).

events.title: FinCEN Drafts Response to French FIU
events.description: FinCEN prepares a response to a French Egmont request investigating a transaction between Gratitude America LTD and a French cultural association.

events.title: Internal U.S. Deconfliction Request
events.description: Internal U.S. government email requests deconfliction with the FBI to approve disseminating FinCEN's report on the Epstein-linked transaction to the French FIU.

events.title: Deconfliction Approval
events.description: An official states they have no objection to sharing the FinCEN report with France, as the dates do not conflict with their investigation.

keyFacts: A French financial intelligence unit (TRACFIN) was investigating a 50,000 Euro transaction from Jeffrey Epstein's USVI company, Gratitude America LTD, to the French association 'ASSOCIATION POUR LA PROMOTION DE LA POLITIQUE CULTURELLE'.
The transaction was flagged for lacking a clear purpose, with suspicions it involved funds from illicit activities, and the French request indicated a potential link to 'a former French Ministry'.
FinCEN identified Epstein as the beneficial owner of Gratitude America LTD and noted he was flagged as a Politically Exposed Person (PEP) due to ties to high-level U.S. government officials.
Internal U.S. government correspondence shows a deconfliction process to approve sharing FinCEN's findings, including three Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs), with French authorities.
